1.4.1.title: Barriers During Overbalanced Drilling
1.4.1.content:
During conventional overbalanced drilling operations:

**Primary Barrier:**
Drilling fluid providing hydrostatic overbalance to formation pressure

**Secondary Barrier:**
BOP system (including casing, cement, wellhead)

**Barrier Elements:**
| Primary | Secondary |
|---------|----------|
| Drilling fluid column | Casing |
| Open hole formation | Cement |
| | BOP rams/annular |
| | Wellhead |

**Monitoring:**
- Continuous pit volume monitoring
- Flow monitoring
- Mud weight verification
- BOP function testing per schedule

1.4.2.title: Barriers During MPD Operations
1.4.2.content:
Managed Pressure Drilling modifies the barrier configuration:

**Primary Barrier:**
Hydrostatic head + Annular friction losses + Surface applied back pressure (SBP)

**Secondary Barrier:**
BOP system

**Additional Considerations:**
- RCD (Rotating Control Device) is part of the pressure containment system but NOT a barrier element
- MPD system failure requires immediate transition to conventional well control
- Two barriers must be maintained at all times - MPD does not change this requirement

**Constant BHP MPD:**
SBP compensates for ECD loss during connections. Primary barrier maintained through pressure management.

**Pressurized Mud Cap Drilling (PMCD):**
Special barrier considerations apply. Detailed procedures in Volume 2.

**Dual Gradient Drilling:**
Riser and wellbore may have different fluid systems. Barrier verification must account for both systems.

1.4.3.title: Cemented Casing as a Barrier
1.4.3.content:
Cemented casing can serve as a barrier element when:

**Requirements:**
- Cement provides minimum 500 ft (150m) of coverage above the zone of interest
- Cement provides lateral support and isolation
- Cement integrity verified by:
  - Positive pressure test from inside
  - Cement evaluation log (CBL/VDL) where required
  - Shoe test/LOT indicating formation strength

**Limitations:**
- Cement quality cannot always be verified behind pipe
- Cement can degrade over time
- Mechanical damage can compromise casing

**When cemented casing is a barrier element:**
- Barrier schematic must clearly identify it
- Any work that could affect integrity requires re-verification
- Casing pressure monitoring required

1.4.4.title: Cement Plug as a Barrier
1.4.4.content:
Cement plugs can serve as barrier elements when:

**Requirements:**
- Minimum length per regulatory requirements (typically 100-200 ft)
- Set across competent formation or inside casing
- Verified by:
  - Positive pressure test from above
  - Weight test (set down) from above
  - Negative test where applicable
  - Tagging with drillstring

**Plug Types:**
- Balanced plug in open hole
- Plug inside casing
- Plug at casing shoe

**Abandonment:**
For permanent abandonment, cement plug barriers must meet regulatory requirements for:
- Isolation of hydrocarbon zones
- Protection of freshwater zones
- Long-term integrity

1.4.5.title: Barriers in Producing Wells
1.4.5.content:
During production operations, typical barriers include:

**Primary Barrier:**
- Completion fluid
- Tubing
- Packer
- SSSV (Subsurface Safety Valve)

**Secondary Barrier:**
- Completion fluid in annulus
- Production casing
- Cement
- Wellhead
- Christmas tree

**Monitoring:**
- Tubing and annulus pressure monitoring
- SSSV function testing per schedule
- Wellhead integrity verification

1.4.6.title: Barriers During Well Intervention
1.4.6.content:
Well intervention operations require maintained barriers throughout:

**Wireline Operations:**
- Primary: Well fluid + BOP/lubricator + wireline valve
- Secondary: SSSV or equivalent isolation

**Coiled Tubing Operations:**
- Primary: Well fluid + CT BOP + check valves
- Secondary: SSSV or equivalent + casing/cement

**Snubbing Operations:**
- Primary: Well fluid + snubbing BOP + IBOP/check valve
- Secondary: Production BOP + casing/cement

**Common Requirements:**
- Verify barriers before entry to well
- Test intervention BOP
- Confirm SSSV or isolation status
- Maintain kill weight fluid available

1.4.7.title: Barriers During P&A Operations
1.4.7.content:
Plug and Abandonment requires progressive barrier installation:

**Phase Approach:**
1. Verify existing barriers before starting
2. Remove completion while maintaining barriers
3. Install permanent cement barriers
4. Verify each barrier before proceeding
5. Final wellhead removal with barriers in place below

**Permanent Barriers:**
- Must isolate all hydrocarbon zones
- Must protect all freshwater zones
- Must meet regulatory requirements
- Must be verified before wellhead removal

**During P&A:**
At all times until final barriers are verified, two barriers must be maintained. This may include:
- Existing cement + fluid column
- Installed plug + fluid column
- Multiple cement plugs

1.4.8.title: Temporary BOP Retrieval
1.4.8.content:
If BOP must be retrieved for maintenance while well has potential for flow:

**Requirements:**
- Well must be secured with verified barriers that do not rely on BOP
- Typically: cement plug + mechanical plug, or equivalent
- Risk assessment required
- Approval from appropriate management level

**Procedure:**
1. Verify barriers independent of BOP
2. Pressure test barriers
3. Displace well to appropriate fluid
4. Monitor well before, during, and after BOP retrieval
5. Have contingency equipment available

**Note:** This is a high-risk operation requiring detailed planning and approval.
